Importation of vegetables from neighboring countries have generated a lot of concern among many in the business community, Donors, and development partners since the country has the most fertile land and water resources suitable for production of agricultural products. As a result millions of dollars were injected into the sector by the Donor Community to address the production gap through projects particularly supporting horticultural production in South Sudan and this intervention yielded little results. This is because the approach was focused on emergency programs supporting only producers and other important actors are missing and this continues to yield less impact on increasing horticulture production. Many of the farming communities in south Sudan still rely on subsistences vegetable /horticulture production. However, some individual progressive farmers do produce for the local market. At the Governors Forum in 2012, a presidential decree was ordered to stop the importation of horticulture product by 2014 in south Sudan. This was noted with a lot of doubt since the faming household in South Sudan are not able to meet the consumer demand which is addressed by the imported horticultural products. This is due to inadequate knowledge and skills, poor horticultural seeds, poor post harvesting practices, lack of packaging materials, inadequate transport facilities, poor infrastructure, pest and disease prevalences among many other challenges, which have been Facing the horticultural sector in South Sudan. The project will therefore address the capacity related challenges to enhance wide production and supply in the market, with a focus on Central Equatoria.

To build on the achievements made, and narrow the existing gaps in developing a functional horticultural production and supply system, the project will target the current progressive horticultural champions in three Counties. A total of 12 champions and one Association with 60 Association members are expected to be directly involved in horticultural production. Efforts will be made in encouraging the target champions/Association members.
While an additional 60 farmers having 60% representation of youth farmers will undergo capacity building on staple food crop production aimed at addressing the existing food gap and taking the WFP (P4P) as market opportunity for famers.
Implementation of the project will be through collaborative networking with RSS Ministry on Agriculture, Forestry, Cooperative and Rural Development (MoAF), South Sudan Agricultural Research and Organization (SSARO), State Ministry of Agriculture (SmoA) and the implementing Actors including local leaders at county, payam and boma levels.
The Technical capacity building to the association orticulture members and chmapions Is expected to meet the local production challenges at community level as well as increasing opportunity for business development on horticulture production. An expected 90 MT of horticultural products is to be produced by the end of the Year 2014. This is expected to increase supply of fresh horticultural products to meet the high growing demand for local consumption in South Sudan.
Based on the agro-ecological suitability, the proposed intervention will be implemented in the following production areas (counties) within CES. Yei County in CES Morobo County in CES Juba County in CES.
Horticulture is one of the profitable enterprise based on its use and demand, therefore building the capacity of the champions/association members on entrepreneurship in horticulture will make farming more beneficial for the community compared to subsistence activities. It was noted that horticulture production is one of the labor intensive farming activities and therefore, there is a great opportunity to increase the amount of available jobs for young South Sudanese Youth. Improving the production skills and increasing yields and income of the Youths members amongst the horticulture association members and champions would motivate the others youths who are idle in town to become horticulture farmers since majority of them are able groups that are capable of physical labour and once they see the income potential reached by other youth, they will be interested to follow.
Efforts are needed to increase yield per unit areas (vertical expansion) rather than horizontal expansions (more land on production). Its anticipated that use of best Agronomic practices, improving soil fertility through natural means (organic), use of improved seed varieties and reducing post harvesting losses on perishability will increase production without use of external inputs and this will cut down cost of production.
